TEXT: The applicant is a NORP citizen . He was born in DATE and lives in GPE , GPE , in GPE . He is represented before the ORG by ORG , solicitors , and Mr PERSON , counsel , practising in GPE , GPE , and GPE respectively .

On DATE an enforcement notice was issued and served on PERSON under LAW of ORG DATE ( “ TCPA DATE ” ) . The notice recited that there appeared to ORG ( “ the ORG ” ) to be a breach of planning control in that a CARDINAL - storey building had been erected to the rear of CARDINAL and CARDINAL FAC , GPE , and of CARDINAL and FAC , GPE , without the necessary planning permission . The notice required the applicant to remove all parts of the building which were QUANTITY above the original ground level , within DATE of DATE . The notice complied on its face with the provisions of the TCPA DATE .
On DATE ORG DATE ( “ TCPA DATE ” ) entered into force , consolidating the previous legislation including the TCPA DATE .

The applicant appealed to the Secretary of ORG for the Environment under section CARDINAL of the TCPA DATE . Section CARDINAL lists CARDINAL grounds upon which appeals may be brought . The applicant appealed on CARDINAL grounds :
“ ( a ) that planning permission ought to be granted for the development to which the notice relates ....
( b ) that the matters alleged in the notice do not constitute a breach of planning control ;
( c ) that the breach of planning control alleged in the notice has not taken place ;
( g ) that the steps required by the notice to be taken exceed what is necessary to ... achieve a purpose specified in section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ... ”

In accordance with the TCPA DATE , an inspector was appointed to determine the appeal against the enforcement notice . Neither the applicant nor the ORG requested a formal public hearing or public inquiry . The inspector made her decision after inspecting the building and considering written representations from both parties . In her decision letter dated DATE , the inspector rejected the appeal under all CARDINAL grounds .

The applicant did not appeal against the decision of the inspector , and on DATE , the enforcement notice came into effect . The applicant remained the owner of the LOC , and did not reduce the structure to a height of QUANTITY as required by the notice .

On DATE , a summons was issued alleging that the applicant had committed a criminal offence under LAW , by failing to remove parts of the building QUANTITY . The applicant was granted legal aid for his representation in criminal proceedings by solicitors and counsel .

The applicant ’s legal advisers sought and obtained disclosure of documents from the ORG . On the basis of these documents , the legal advisers wished to argue that there had been bad faith , including bias and improper motives , on the part of a Councillor in connection with the decision to issue the enforcement notice . The applicant ’s counsel advised him that an application for leave to move for judicial review , and thereby directly challenge in separate proceedings the decision to issue the enforcement notice , would have no reasonable prospect of success , being DATE out of time .

The criminal trial took place on CARDINAL and DATE at ORG , before His Honour Judge PERSON and a jury . The judge ruled that the applicant was not entitled to contend , as a defence in the criminal proceedings , that the decision to issue the enforcement notice had been influenced by bias and bad faith , as a challenge to the enforcement notice could only be brought by way of proceedings for judicial review . Consequently , the applicant changed his plea from “ not guilty ” to “ guilty ” .
The applicant appealed against the conviction on the basis that the ruling of His Honour Judge PERSON had been wrong . On DATE , ORG ) dismissed the appeal . On DATE , ORG granted leave to appeal .

A hearing took place before ORG on CARDINAL and DATE and , on CARDINAL DATE , ORG dismissed the applicant ’s appeal ( [ DATE ] Appeal Cases CARDINAL ) . ORG held that “ enforcement notice ” in section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the TCPA DATE meant a notice issued by a planning authority which , on its face , complied with the requirements of the LAW and had not been quashed on appeal or by judicial review . The effect of this was that , to constitute a defence in the criminal proceedings , the validity of an enforcement notice would have to be challenged within the time limits for a statutory appeal under the TCPA DATE or for an application for judicial review . It noted that the statutory grounds of appeal against an enforcement notice were wide enough to include every aspect of the merits of the decision to serve an enforcement notice . An application for judicial review would in practice be needed only for the rare case in which enforcement was objectively justifiable but the decision that service of the notice was “ expedient ” ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(b ) ) was vitiated by some impropriety .
